  1 dir = File.dirname(__FILE__)

  4 # = Sass (Syntactically Awesome StyleSheets)
  5 #
  6 # Sass is a meta-language on top of CSS
  7 # that's used to describe the style of a document
  8 # cleanly and structurally,
  9 # with more power than flat CSS allows.
 10 # Sass both provides a simpler, more elegant syntax for CSS
 11 # and implements various features that are useful
 12 # for creating manageable stylesheets.
 13 #
 14 # == Features 
 15 #
 16 # * Whitespace active
 17 # * Well-formatted output
 18 # * Elegant input
 19 # * Feature-rich
 20 #
 21 # == Using Sass
 22 #
 23 # Sass can be used in two ways:
 24 # As a plugin for Ruby on Rails
 25 # and as a standalone parser.
 26 # Sass is bundled with Haml,
 27 # so if the Haml plugin or RubyGem is installed,
 28 # Sass will already be installed as a plugin or gem, respectively.
 29 #
 30 # To install Haml and Sass as a Ruby on Rails plugin,
 31 # use the normal Rails plugin installer:
 32 #
 33 #   ./script/plugin install http://svn.hamptoncatlin.com/haml/tags/stable
 34 #
 35 # Sass templates in Rails don't quite function in the same way as views,
 36 # because they don't contain dynamic content,
 37 # and so only need to be compiled when the template file has been updated.
 38 # By default (see options, below),
 39 # ".sass" files are placed in public/stylesheets/sass.
 40 # Then, whenever necessary, they're compiled into corresponding CSS files in public/stylesheets.
 41 # For instance, public/stylesheets/sass/main.sass would be compiled to public/stylesheets/main.css.
 42 #
 43 # Using Sass in Ruby code is very simple.
 44 # First install the Haml/Sass RubyGem:
 45 #
 46 #   gem install haml
 47 #
 48 # Then you can use it by including the "sass" gem
 49 # and using Sass::Engine like so:
 50 #
 51 #   engine = Sass::Engine.new("#main\n  :background-color #0000ff")
 52 #   engine.render #=> "#main { background-color: #0000ff; }\n"
 53 #
 54 # == CSS Rules
 55 #
 56 # Rules in flat CSS have two elements:
 57 # the selector
 58 # (e.g. "#main", "div p", "li a:hover")
 59 # and the attributes
 60 # (e.g. "color: #00ff00;", "width: 5em;").
 61 #
 62 # Sass has both of these,
 63 # as well as one additional element: nested rules.
 64 #
 65 # === Rules and Selectors
 66 #
 67 # However, some of the syntax is a little different.
 68 # The syntax for selectors is the same,
 69 # but instead of using brackets to delineate the attributes that belong to a particular rule,
 70 # Sass uses two spaces of indentation.
 71 # For example:
 72 #
 73 #   #main p
 74 #     <attribute>
 75 #     <attribute>
 76 #     ...
 77 #
 78 # === Attributes
 79 #
 80 # The syntax for attributes is also slightly different.
 81 # The colon is at the beginning of the attribute,
 82 # rather than between the name and the value,
 83 # so it's easier to tell what elements are attributes just by glancing at them.
 84 # Attributes also don't have semicolons at the end;
 85 # each attribute is on its own line, so they aren't necessary.
 86 # For example:
 87 #
 88 #   #main p
 89 #     :color #00ff00
 90 #     :width 97%
 91 #
 92 # is compiled to:
 93 #
 94 #   #main p {
 95 #     color: #00ff00;
 96 #     width: 97% }
 97 #
 98 # === Nested Rules
 99 #
100 # Rules can also be nested within each other.
101 # This signifies that the inner rule's selector is a child of the outer selector.
102 # For example:
103 #
104 #   #main p
105 #     :color #00ff00
106 #     :width 97%
107 #
108 #     .redbox
109 #       :background-color #ff0000
110 #       :color #000000
111 #
112 # is compiled to:
113 #
114 #   #main p {
115 #     color: #00ff00;
116 #     width: 97%; }
117 #     #main p .redbox {
118 #       background-color: #ff0000;
119 #       color: #000000; }
120 #
121 # This makes insanely complicated CSS layouts with lots of nested selectors very simple:
122 #
123 #   #main
124 #     :width 97%
125 #     
126 #     p, div
127 #       :font-size 2em
128 #       a
129 #         :font-weight bold
130 #         
131 #     pre
132 #       :font-size 3em
133 #
134 # is compiled to:
135 #
136 #   #main {
137 #     width: 97%; }
138 #     #main p, #main div {
139 #       font-size: 2em; }
140 #       #main p a, #main div a {
141 #         font-weight: bold; }
142 #     #main pre {
143 #       font-size: 3em; }
144 #
145 # === Referencing Parent Rules
146 #
147 # In addition to the default behavior of inserting the parent selector
148 # as a CSS parent of the current selector
149 # (e.g. above, "#main" is the parent of "p"),
150 # you can have more fine-grained control over what's done with the parent selector
151 # by using the ampersand character "&" in your selectors.
152 #
153 # The ampersand is automatically replaced by the parent selector,
154 # instead of having it prepended.
155 # This allows you to cleanly create pseudo-attributes:
156 #
157 #   a
158 #     :font-weight bold
159 #     :text-decoration none
160 #     &:hover
161 #       :text-decoration underline
162 #     &:visited
163 #       :font-weight normal
164 #
165 # Which would become:
166 #
167 #   a {
168 #     font-weight: bold;
169 #     text-decoration: none; }
170 #     a:hover {
171 #       text-decoration: underline; }
172 #     a:visited {
173 #       font-weight: normal; }
174 #
175 # It also allows you to add selectors at the base of the hierarchy,
176 # which can be useuful for targeting certain styles to certain browsers:
177 #
178 #   #main
179 #     :width 90%
180 #     #sidebar
181 #       :float left
182 #       :margin-left 20%
183 #       .ie6 &
184 #         :margin-left 40%
185 #
186 # Which would become:
187 #
188 #   #main {
189 #     width: 90%; }
190 #     #main #sidebar {
191 #       float: left;
192 #       margin-left: 20%; }
193 #       .ie6 #main #sidebar {
194 #         margin-left: 40%; }
195 #
196 # === Attribute Namespaces
197 #
198 # CSS has quite a few attributes that are in "namespaces;"
199 # for instance, "font-family," "font-size," and "font-weight"
200 # are all in the "font" namespace.
201 # In CSS, if you want to set a bunch of attributes in the same namespace,
202 # you have to type it out each time.
203 # Sass offers a shortcut for this:
204 # just write the namespace one,
205 # then indent each of the sub-attributes within it.
206 # For example:
207 #
208 #   .funky
209 #     :font
210 #       :family fantasy
211 #       :size 30em
212 #       :weight bold
213 #
214 # is compiled to:
215 #
216 #   .funky {
217 #     font-family: fantasy;
218 #     font-size: 30em;
219 #     font-weight: bold; }
220 #
221 # == Constants
222 #
223 # Sass has support for setting document-wide constants.
224 # They're set using an exclamation mark followed by the name,
225 # an equals sign, and the value.
226 # An attribute can then be set to the value of a constant
227 # by following it with another equals sign.
228 # For example:
229 #
230 #   !main_color = #00ff00
231 #
232 #   #main
233 #     :color = !main_color
234 #     :p
235 #       :background-color = !main_color
236 #       :color #000000
237 #
238 # is compiled to:
239 #
240 #   #main {
241 #     color: #00ff00; }
242 #     #main p {
243 #       background-color: #00ff00;
244 #       color: #000000; }
245 #
246 # === Arithmetic
247 #
248 # You can even do basic arithmetic with constants.
249 # Sass recognizes numbers, colors,
250 # lengths (numbers with units),
251 # and strings (everything that's not one of the above),
252 # and various operators that work on various values.
253 # All the normal arithmetic operators
254 # (+, -, *, /, %, and parentheses for grouping)
255 # are defined as usual
256 # for numbers, colors, and lengths.
257 # The "+" operator is also defined for Strings
258 # as the concatenation operator.
259 # For example:
260 #
261 #   !main_width = 10
262 #   !unit1 = em
263 #   !unit2 = px
264 #   !bg_color = #a5f39e
265 #
266 #   #main
267 #     :background-color = !bg_color
268 #     p
269 #       :background-color = !bg_color + #202020
270 #       :width = !main_width + !unit1
271 #     img.thumb
272 #       :width = (!main_width + 15) + !unit2
273 #
274 # is compiled to:
275 #
276 #   #main {
277 #     background-color: #a5f39e; }
278 #     #main p {
279 #       background-color: #c5ffbe;
280 #       width: 10em; }
281 #     #main img.thumb {
282 #       width: 25em; }
283 #
284 # === Colors
285 #
286 # Colors may be written as three- or six-digit hex numbers prefixed
287 # by a pound sign (#), or as HTML4 color names. For example,
288 # "#ff0", "#ffff00" and "yellow" all refer to the same color.
289 #
290 # Not only can arithmetic be done between colors and other colors,
291 # but it can be done between colors and normal numbers.
292 # In this case, the operation is done piecewise one each of the
293 # Red, Green, and Blue components of the color.
294 # For example:
295 #
296 #   !main_color = #a5f39e
297 #
298 #   #main
299 #     :background-color = !main_color
300 #     p
301 #       :background-color = !bg_color + 32
302 #
303 # is compiled to:
304 #
305 #   #main {
306 #     background-color: #a5f39e; }
307 #     #main p {
308 #       background-color: #c5ffbe; }
309 #
310 # === Strings
311 #
312 # Strings are the type that's used by default
313 # when an element in a bit of constant arithmetic isn't recognized
314 # as another type of constant.
315 # However, they can also be created explicitly be wrapping a section of code with quotation marks.
316 # Inside the quotation marks,
317 # a backslash can be used to
318 # escape quotation marks that you want to appear in the CSS.
319 # For example:
320 #
321 #   !content = "Hello, \"Hubert\" Bean."
322 #
323 #   #main
324 #     :content = "string(" + !content + ")"
325 #
326 # is compiled to:
327 #
328 #   #main {
329 #     content: string(Hello, "Hubert" Bean.) }
330 #
331 # === Default Concatenation
332 #
333 # All those plusses and quotes for concatenating strings
334 # can get pretty messy, though.
335 # Most of the time, if you want to concatenate stuff,
336 # you just want individual values with spaces in between them.
337 # Thus, in Sass, when two values are next to each other without an operator,
338 # they're simply joined with a space.
339 # For example:
340 #
341 #   !font_family = sans-serif
342 #   !main_font_size = 1em
343 #
344 #   #main
345 #     :font
346 #       :family = !font-family
347 #       :size = !main_font_size
348 #     h6
349 #       :font = italic small-caps bold (!main_font_size + 0.1em) !font-family
350 #
351 # is compiled to:
352 #
353 #   #main {
354 #     font-family: sans-serif;
355 #     font-size: 1em; }
356 #     #main h6 {
357 #       font: italic small-caps bold 1.1em sans-serif; }
358 #
359 # == Directives
360 #
361 # Directives allow the author to directly issue instructions to the Sass compiler.
362 # They're prefixed with an at sign, "<tt>@</tt>",
363 # followed by the name of the directive,
364 # a space, and any arguments to it -
365 # just like CSS directives.
366 # For example:
367 #
368 #   @import red.sass
369 #
370 # === Import
371 #
372 # Currently, the only directive is the "import" directive.
373 # It works in a very similar way to the CSS import directive,
374 # and sometimes compiles to a literal CSS "@import".
375 #
376 # Sass can import either other Sass files or plain CSS files.
377 # If it imports a Sass file,
378 # not only are the rules from that file included,
379 # but all constants in that file are made available in the current file.
380 #
381 # Sass looks for other Sass files in the working directory,
382 # and the Sass file directory under Rails.
383 # Additional search directories may be specified
384 # using the :load_paths option (see below).
385 #
386 # Sass can also import plain CSS files.
387 # In this case, it doesn't literally include the content of the files;
388 # rather, it uses the built-in CSS "@import" directive to tell the client program
389 # to import the files.
390 #
391 # The import directive can take either a full filename
392 # or a filename without an extension.
393 # If an extension isn't provided,
394 # Sass will try to find a Sass file with the given basename in the load paths,
395 # and, failing that, will assume a relevant CSS file will be available.
396 #
397 # For example,
398 #
399 #   @import foo.sass
400 #
401 # would compile to
402 #
403 #   .foo
404 #     :color #f00
405 #
406 # whereas
407 #
408 #   @import foo.css
409 #
410 # would compile to
411 #
412 #   @import foo.css
413 #
414 # Finally,
415 #
416 #  @import foo
417 #
418 # might compile to either,
419 # depending on whether a file called "foo.sass" existed.
420 #
421 # == Comments
422 #
423 # === Silent Comments
424 #
425 # It's simple to add "silent" comments,
426 # which don't output anything to the CSS document,
427 # to a Sass document.
428 # Simply use the familiar C-style notation for a one-line comment, "//",
429 # at the normal indentation level and all text following it won't be output.
430 # For example:
431 #
432 #   // A very awesome rule.
433 #   #awesome.rule
434 #     // An equally awesome attribute.
435 #     :awesomeness very
436 #
437 # becomes
438 #
439 #   #awesome.rule {
440 #     awesomeness: very; }
441 #
442 # === Loud Comments
443 #
444 # "Loud" comments are just as easy as silent ones.
445 # These comments output to the document as CSS comments,
446 # and thus use the same opening sequence: "/*".
447 # For example:
448 #
449 #   /* A very awesome rule.
450 #   #awesome.rule
451 #     /* An equally awesome attribute.
452 #     :awesomeness very
453 #
454 # becomes
455 #
456 #   /* A very awesome rule. */
457 #   #awesome.rule {
458 #     /* An equally awesome attribute. */
459 #     awesomeness: very; }
460 #
461 # == Output Style
462 #
463 # Although the default CSS style that Sass outputs is very nice,
464 # and reflects the structure of the document in a similar way that Sass does,
465 # sometimes it's good to have other formats available.
466 #
467 # Sass allows you to choose between three different output styles
468 # by setting the <tt>:style</tt> option.
469 # In Rails, this is done by setting <tt>Sass::Template.options[:style]</tt>;
470 # outside Rails, it's done by passing an options hash with </tt>:style</tt> set.
471 #
472 # === <tt>:nested</tt>
473 #
474 # Nested style is the default Sass style,
475 # because it reflects the structure of the document
476 # in much the same way Sass does.
477 # Each attribute has its own line,
478 # but the indentation isn't constant.
479 # Each rule is indented based on how deeply it's nested.
480 # For example:
481 #
482 #   #main {
483 #     color: #fff;
484 #     background-color: #000; }
485 #     #main p {
486 #       width: 10em; }
487 #
488 #   .huge {
489 #     font-size: 10em;
490 #     font-weight: bold;
491 #     text-decoration: underline; }
492 #
493 # Nested style is very useful when looking at large CSS files
494 # for the same reason Sass is useful for making them:
495 # it allows you to very easily grasp the structure of the file
496 # without actually reading anything.
497 #
498 # === <tt>:expanded</tt>
499 #
500 # Expanded is the typical human-made CSS style,
501 # with each attribute and rule taking up one line.
502 # Attributes are indented within the rules,
503 # but the rules aren't indented in any special way.
504 # For example:
505 #
506 #   #main {
507 #     color: #fff;
508 #     background-color: #000;
509 #   }
510 #   #main p {
511 #     width: 10em;
512 #   }
513 #
514 #   .huge {
515 #     font-size: 10em;
516 #     font-weight: bold;
517 #     text-decoration: underline;
518 #   }
519 #
520 # === <tt>:compact</tt>
521 #
522 # Compact style, as the name would imply,
523 # takes up less space than Nested or Expanded.
524 # However, it's also harder to read.
525 # Each CSS rule takes up only one line,
526 # with every attribute defined on that line.
527 # Nested rules are placed next to each other with no newline,
528 # while groups of rules have newlines between them.
529 # For example:
530 #
531 #   #main { color: #fff; background-color: #000; }
532 #   #main p { width: 10em; }
533 #
534 #   .huge { font-size: 10em; font-weight: bold; text-decoration: underline; } 
535 #
536 # == Sass Options
537 #
538 # Options can be set by setting the hash <tt>Sass::Plugin.options</tt>
539 # from <tt>environment.rb</tt> in Rails,
540 # or by passing an options hash to Sass::Engine.
541 # Available options are:
542 #
543 # [<tt>:style</tt>]             Sets the style of the CSS output.
544 #                               See the section on Output Style, above.
545 #
546 # [<tt>:always_update</tt>]     Whether the CSS files should be updated every
547 #                               time a controller is accessed,
548 #                               as opposed to only when the template has been modified.
549 #                               Defaults to false.
550 #                               Only has meaning within Ruby on Rails.
551 #                               
552 # [<tt>:always_check</tt>]      Whether a Sass template should be checked for updates every
553 #                               time a controller is accessed,
554 #                               as opposed to only when the Rails server starts.
555 #                               If a Sass template has been updated,
556 #                               it will be recompiled and will overwrite the corresponding CSS file.
557 #                               Defaults to false if Rails is running in production mode,
558 #                               true otherwise.
559 #                               Only has meaning within Ruby on Rails.
560 #
561 # [<tt>:template_location</tt>] The directory where Sass templates should be read from.
562 #                               Defaults to <tt>RAILS_ROOT + "/public/stylesheets/sass"</tt>.
563 #                               Only has meaning within Ruby on Rails.
564 #
565 # [<tt>:css_location</tt>]      The directory where CSS output should be written to.
566 #                               Defaults to <tt>RAILS_ROOT + "/public/stylesheets"</tt>.
567 #                               Only has meaning within Ruby on Rails.
568 #
569 # [<tt>:filename</tt>]          The filename of the file being rendered.
570 #                               This is used solely for reporting errors,
571 #                               and is automatically set when using Rails.
572 #
573 # [<tt>:load_paths</tt>]        An array of filesystem paths which should be searched
574 #                               for Sass templates imported with the "@import" directive.
575 #                               This defaults to the working directory and, in Rails,
576 #                               whatever <tt>:template_location</tt> is
577 #                               (by default <tt>RAILS_ROOT + "/public/stylesheets/sass"</tt>).
578 # 
579 module Sass; end
580 
581 require 'sass/engine'

Generated using the rcov code coverage analysis tool for Ruby version 0.8.0.
